segments.text: After two years I remember the rest of that day, the night, and the next day only as an endless drill of police, photographers, and newspaper men streaming in and out of Gatsby’s front door. A rope had been stretched across the main gate with a lone policeman guarding it, while curious children discovered a secret path through my yard, gawking open-mouthed around the pool. In the midst of it all, a detective – or perhaps someone with a positive manner – had muttered the word “madman” while bending over Wilson’s body, his authoritative tone setting the stage for the newspaper reports the following morning.

segments.text: Most of the reports were grotesque mixtures of nightmare, circumstantial evidence, eagerness, and falsehoods. When Michaelis testified about Wilson’s suspicions regarding his wife, I expected the tale to burst into scandal. Instead, Catherine – with a steely look and determined eyes beneath her carefully raised brow – simply denied that her sister had ever seen Gatsby. She declared that her sister was content with her husband and had committed no mischief whatsoever. Her quiet strength and silent tears as she cradled her handkerchief transformed Wilson into a man ‘deranged by grief’ – a convenient simplification to keep the case uncomplicated.

segments.text: In that moment, I found myself on Gatsby’s side, feeling alone in a sea of curiosity and detachment. Every question and surmise that followed the catastrophe was directed towards me, and as Gatsby lay unmoving in his mansion – silent and still – I internalized a responsibility that no one else would claim.

segments.text: (On the telephone, urgently) I called up Daisy half an hour after we found him. 'Left no address?' I asked. 'No,' the reply came curtly. I pressed, 'Say when they’d be back?' Again, 'No.' 'Any idea where they are? How I could reach them?' The response was flat: 'I don’t know. Can’t say.'

segments.text: I longed to reassure Gatsby personally – to step into the room where he lay and whisper, 'I’ll get somebody for you, Gatsby. Don’t worry. Just trust me – I’ll get somebody for you.' But attempts to reach Meyer Wolfsheim were thwarted: his name wasn’t even in the phone book. Following the butler’s directions to his Broadway office, I eventually reached an unanswered number, even after multiple rings.

segments.text: Shortly after, the solemn figure of Mr. Gatz arrived at the mansion. An old man in a long, cheap ulster, his eyes overflowed with excitement and everlasting grief. When I retrieved his bag and umbrella, he fumbled with his sparse grey beard – almost on the verge of collapse. I guided him into the music room, where he sat uncomfortably as I arranged for something to eat. He insisted, 'I saw it in the Chicago newspaper. It was all in the Chicago newspaper,' and his disjointed reference to a ‘madman’ echoed his fragile grasp on reality.

segments.text: (On the phone) 'This is Mr. Carraway,' I introduced. 'Oh!' came a relieved, though vague, response: 'This is Klipspringer.' I mentioned, 'The funeral’s tomorrow at three o’clock, here at the house. I wish you’d tell anybody who’d be interested.' He hesitated, 'Oh, I will. Of course I’m not likely to see anybody, but if I do…' I pressed, 'Of course you’ll be there yourself.' After a pause, he added nervously, 'I’m staying with some people in Greenwich – there’s a picnic or something. I’ll do my best to get away…' Then, almost as an afterthought, 'What I called up about was a pair of tennis shoes I left there. Could the butler send them on? My address is...'
segments.voice_traits: nervous stutter in parts, hesitant intonation, fast but uncertain pacing with defensive undertones

segments.text: Later that morning I ventured into New York in search of Meyer Wolfsheim. The meeting took place in an unassuming office behind a door labeled 'The Swastika Holding Company.' At first, silence reigned until a sharply observant, hostile-voiced Jewess stepped forward, insisting that Wolfsheim was in Chicago and that no one could force their way in. Moments later, Wolfshiem himself emerged – holding out his hands, his tone steeped in reverence and sorrow as he recalled the early days with Gatsby: 'I met him as a young major, barely out of the war. He was so hard up he wore his uniform because he couldn’t afford proper clothes.'
segments.voice_traits: steady, reflective, with measured reverence and a nostalgic lilt, punctuated by soft sighs of regret

segments.text: After Wolfsheim’s account, I encountered another figure from the periphery – Tom Buchanan. On a brisk afternoon along Fifth Avenue, he walked in his alert, aggressive manner until our eyes met through a shop window. With an outstretched hand he greeted me, 'What’s the matter, Nick? Do you object to shaking hands with me?' His tone was patronizing, even as our conversation spiraled into accusations about the events that unfolded that fateful afternoon with Wilson and the cover-up that followed.
segments.voice_traits: assertive, clipped, with a sneer evident in his tone; brisk delivery and slightly mocking inflection

segments.text: 'I told him the truth,' he declared, gripping my arm. 'He came to the door as we were leaving, and when I sent word we weren’t in, he tried to force his way upstairs! The man was crazy – his hand never left his revolver. And what if I had told him? That fellow got what was coming. He threw dust in your eyes just like in Daisy’s, but he was a tough one – he ran over Myrtle as if she were a dog, and he never stopped!'
segments.voice_traits: harsh, forceful, with a rising anger; rapid intonation and a rough, dismissive edge
segments.character_voice_traits: He speaks in a gruff, husky tenor that reinforces his brutish character. There is a hint of paternal or even condescending contempt in his tone, suggesting that his voice serves as an extension of his forceful, domineering nature.

segments.text: I could only offer the one silent counterpoint – the undeniable truth that his twisted rendition was not what truly happened. As the day wore on, I reflected on the carelessness of Tom and Daisy – how they had smashed apart lives and retreated back into their money and indifference, leaving others to clean up the resulting mess.

segments.text: Gatsby’s house remained empty after his death, the long grass on the lawn mirroring the neglect and finality of his absence. The memory of his dazzling parties—its music, laughter, and the ceaseless rumble of cars—lingered like ghostly echoes. One last time, before leaving, I walked up the white steps and erased an obscene word scrawled on the stone, and then I strolled down to the beach to brood on the inescapable transience of dreams.
segments.voice_traits: reflective, somber, with a slow, mournful pace and gentle pauses that evoke a fading dream

segments.text: In my final reflections, as I sat quietly on that darkening beach, the image of Gatsby’s green light flashed in my mind – a beacon of hope, a dream receding into the vast obscurity of the past. Gatsby believed in that green light and a future always just a little too far away. And as I contemplated how we all drift on like boats against the current, I realized that, despite everything, we are all inevitably borne back into our own pasts.
